courses.name: Introduction to Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: The course introduces students to key concepts and issues in the three related disciplines at the core of our program: drama, theatre, and performance studies. We consider broader questions of performance and performativity in daily life alongside the questions of what goes into the making of a stage-based performance and the responsibilities of artists, presenters, and witnesses in this endeavour. Engaging critically with theoretical and dramatic texts and live performances, students learn how to think about performance in its cultural, social, aesthetic and political dimensions, and how to acknowledge and navigate their own responsibilities as culture workers situated in specific historical and contemporary contexts. This course combines weekly two-hour lectures with one-hour tutorials.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: DRM100Y1, DRE121H5, DRE122H5, VPDA10H3, VPDA11H3, VPDA10H3, VPDA15H3, VPDB10H3, VPDB11H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must sign up for a tutorial. They will be informed of their assigned tutorial room in the first week of class.

Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous online course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes (Tuesday 9am -11am EST) and one online tutorial (Tuesday 11am-12pm or 12-1pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: Emphasis is initially placed on ensemble, non-verbal, and improvisational work. Students proceed to the application of their acquired skills to scripted material. Students may apply in their first or second year of University. The Application Deadline is March 10th for the first round of auditions; August 10th for the second round. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Performance I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: An audition and interview in April or in August. Newly admitted students can apply for an audition before beginning their first year of studies.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: DRS221H5 AND DRS222H5; VPDB01H3 AND VPDB02H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Selection is based on an audition & interview. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. First round of applications were due March 10th. The second round application (including audition video) is due by August 10th, followed by an online interview in mid-August. Students can apply straight out of high school: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login 

Delivery Instructions

This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes and in-person or workshops and group work sessions. Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to directing theatre and to the different styles, concerns, and goals that can guide directors in their relations to actors, audiences, and politics. Through lectures, discussions, and practical exercises, students learn how directors prepare for their work in terms of generating ideas, breaking down a text, animating space, and communicating with actors and audiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directing I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama; DRM101Y1
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1

Distribution Requirement: Humanities

Breadth Requirement: Creative and Cultural Representations (1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous online course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes (Monday 5-8pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will introduce students to major developments in world theatre history through the exploration of a wide range of plays, performances, and practices. In the Fall term our trajectory will go roughly from antiquity to the 16th Century; in the Winter term, from the 16th Century to the present. We will examine material from Africa, America, Asia, Europe, and Oceania, with close attention to the social, religious, historical, aesthetic, and political parameters in which theatre and performance take place. Nurturing ethnically sensitive approaches to world theatre history, this course considers the many ways theatre and performance interact with the globalized world. Students will have an opportunity to participate in collaborative projects and focus on writing for research in the performing arts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Comparative Theatre Histories
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM101Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: A hands-on study of the craft of dramatic writing. The class examines the basic elements of playwriting such as plot, structure, theme, character, dialogue, setting, with an emphasis on story-making. Attention is given to the development of students own work through written assignments and in-class exercises.
cmCourseInfo.title: Playwriting I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama; DRM101Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical and theoretical introduction to the fundamentals of theatrical performance design. This course touches on theatre architecture, conceptual approaches to theatrical design and spatial considerations of live performance. Students will work on case studies and practical projects geared toward understanding theatre terminology, design, and production processes. Students will also explore concrete aspects of technical theatre production, particularly as they pertain to theatrical design elements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Design and Production I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama

cmCourseInfo.description: A continuation of DRM202H1, concentrating on deepening the exploration of what it means to think and work like a director. Through practical exercises and scene study, students learn how to conceptualize a production and how to communicate their vision, as well as deepen their understanding of what is involved in directing actors and collaborating with a production team. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply and the deadline to apply.

courses.name: Concepts of Theatre in the Twentieth and Twenty-first Centuries

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of the shifting landscapes of European theatre theory, history and practice in the late 19th century and their repercussions throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. The course focuses on the developments of modern and post-dramatic theatre. It also includes critical analysis of the annual Drama Mainstage production and current Canadian theatre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Concepts of Theatre in the Twentieth and Twenty-first Centuries
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM101Y1

notes.name: Course Note

Students develop their own work through written assignments, in-class exercises, and the final public presentation. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply and the deadline to apply.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM101Y1; DRM228H1; and  a portfolio of writing samples due in April.

cmCourseInfo.title: Dramaturgy

notes.name: Course Note

Delivery Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: The turn of the 21st century advanced a social, political, and aesthetic shift reminiscent of that during the post-Industrial Revolution/pre-WWII epoch that launched the historical avant-garde. This class, while exploring significant artistic and sociopolitical developments of the historical avant-garde, will primarily concentrate on the experimental theatre and performance of the past 15 years—a contemporary avant-garde that “hinge[s] on a networked spatiality, rather than on linear teleology” and reflects a growing collective investment on part of audiences and artists alike in the work of a work of art.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Contemporary Avant-Garde
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM101Y1 or any 4.0 FCE

Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be required to attend synchronous online classes (with the knowledge that the instructor may cancel a synchronous class occasionally). The classes will mostly be discussion- or presentation-based depending on the time of the semester. There will be required asynchronous lectures to supplement some weeks’ readings that will be uploaded to Quercus. Students will need access to high-speed internet, a microphone, and a keyboard to participate fully in this class. Although a webcam is not required, (there will be different ways to participate in discussion) a microphone is required.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Performance builds on the training sequence of DRM200Y1 and DRM300Y1 by developing students’ acting and performance skills in monologues, extensive collaborative scene work, and preparations for auditions. The work focuses on the particulars of character development and the emotional and technical aspects of the actor’s craft. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Performance
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM403Y1 or permission of the Centre

Emphasis is placed on the development of strong central concepts and realizing the production with imagination, collaboration and creativity. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.

Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.

courses.name: Arts and Politics: Bertolt Brecht, Giorgio Strehler, Robert Wilson and Robert Lepage

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Oct 6, 2020: time change

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Oct 6, 2020: time change

cmCourseInfo.description: Bertolt Brecht played a specific role in the paradigm shift of the art which began at the end of the 19th century. He advanced this change by trying to connect art to its social and political functions and structure with the positive acceptance of the industrial revolution and by trying to transform it with the help of the new technological media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Arts and Politics: Bertolt Brecht, Giorgio Strehler, Robert Wilson and Robert Lepage
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 9 FCE; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or DRM320H1; Specialist or Major in Drama

Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE; Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; A written proposal; Independent study form signed by both student and faculty instructor to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) before registration: August 1st for September start date; November 1st for January start date.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

A written proposal and an independent study form signed by the faculty member who has agreed to supervise the project must be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) by August 1st.  For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Assignments will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

courses.name: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: September 25, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: A scholarly project at the 400 level proposed by the individual student in conversation with a member of faculty who is willing to act as supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE; Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; A written proposal; Independent study form signed by both student and faculty instructor to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) before registration: August 1st for September start date; November 1st for January start date.

courses.name: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: A scholarly project at the 400 level proposed by the individual student in conversation with a member of faculty who is willing to act as supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE; Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; A written proposal; Independent study form signed by both student and faculty instructor to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) before registration: August 1st for September start date; November 1st for January start date.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

A written proposal and an independent study form signed by the faculty member who has agreed to supervise the project must be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) by November 1st for January start date. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Selected students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.
